image.altText: Grace Tame wearing white shirt and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Tasmania could become the first state to introduce minimum sentences for child sex offenders as Labor flips its position, but the controversial legislation has drawn the ire of legal groups and victim-survivor Grace Tame.

title.children: 'Great in theory': Grace Tame's warning as Tasmanian Labor flips to support mandatory child abuse sentencing

image.altText: optus 'yes' sign on glass fronted office block

items.synopsis: More Australians are reporting being targeted by cyber criminals, as the nation's digital spy agency points the finger at China as the major backer of serious hacking of Australian companies and critical infrastructure.

title.children: Reports of hacking increase, China identified as major culprit

image.altText: A group of women and children on the back of a van

items.synopsis: As a humanitarian disaster unfolds in Gaza, the United States fears a power vacuum will soon follow. But Palestinian leaders say the current ideas for post-war Gaza aren't viable.

title.children: America has an idea for what post-war Gaza could look like. Here's why almost everyone is against it

image.altText: The Riverlea housing project at Buckland Park in Adelaide's north.

items.synopsis: On the one hand is a $3 billion development to accommodate thousands of families. On the other is a burial site that is of immeasurable cultural significance. The problem? They are both on the same ground.

title.children: It looks like an oasis, but the Riverlea development has been harbouring a secret

image.altText: Thousands of people in front of the White House carry signs and wave Israeli flags

items.synopsis: Tens of thousands of demonstrators gather in Washington to show solidarity with Israel in its war with Hamas and condemn rising anti-Semitism, while President Joe Biden says he believes the release of hostages will happen.

title.children: Demonstrators in Washington denounce anti-Semitism, Biden tells hostages to 'hang in there'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A desperate shortage of fuel has led to the deaths of about 40 patients including three premature babies at the besieged Al-Shifa Hospital. The Hamas-run Gaza health ministry says people are unable to leave, as the encirclement of the hospital by Israeli troops makes it too dangerous, Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn reports. Watch the full report below: "Hamas says that Israeli tanks are at the gates of Al-Shifa and there has been heavy gun battles around the vicinity between Israeli troops and Hamas militants," she said. "Because they say they cannot leave, the Hamas-run ministry of health says that now doctors are having to dig mass graves in the vicinity of the hospital to bury those people that have died over the last few days." About 600 patients and 5,000 civilians are stuck sheltering inside the hospital, according to the ministry. Israel claims that Hamas uses the hospital as a shield for military operations, which Hamas and the hospital leadership have denied. The World Health Organization has said that Al-Shifa has stopped functioning as a hospital and that the situation there is perilous.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mass grave dug at Gaza's Al-Shifa as patients die at the besieged hospital, health ministry says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The American president says he believes a deal to free hostages held by Hamas in Gaza is going to happen. Asked by a reporter at the White House if he could "give a message of hope and reslience" for the hostages, Joe Biden said: "Yes I can. I've been talking with the people involved every single day. I believe it's going to happen, but I don't want to get into detail." Asked for his message for the hostages' families, Mr Biden said: "Hang in there. We're coming." About 240 people are believed to have been taken hostage by Hamas during the October 7 attack. The Qatari government has been involved in trying to negotiate their release. Several weeks ago, four were freed — two Americans and two Israelis .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Hang in there': Biden says he believes hostages are set to be released

props.alt: Joe Biden stands at a podium in front of flags and a screen that says 'historic climate action'

children.content: Joe Biden made the remarks after speaking about climate policy at the White House.
(Reuters: Tom Brenner)
The American president says he believes a deal to free hostages held by Hamas in Gaza is going to happen.
Asked by a reporter at the White House if he could "give a message of hope and reslience" for the hostages, Joe Biden said:
"Yes I can. I've been talking with the people involved every single day. I believe it's going to happen, but I don't want to get into detail."
Asked for his message for the hostages' families, Mr Biden said:
"Hang in there. We're coming."
About 240 people are believed to have been taken hostage by Hamas during the October 7 attack. The Qatari government has been involved in trying to negotiate their release.
Several weeks ago, four were freed —
two Americans
and
two Israelis

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's a large rally happening here in Washington right now. Tens of thousands of people have gathered to show support for Israel and oppose anti-Semitism in the United States. The March for Israel event has attracted busloads of demonstrators from all over the country. Many have held up signs showing photos of hostages to chants of "let our people go". Speakers have spoken against a rising wave of hate crimes targeting Jews in the US, which the FBI recently warned was reaching "historic levels". "We are all being tested," actress Debra Messing told the crowd. "A tsunami of hate has crashed down upon us, and then a defeaning silence. We see clearly now — we see naked, virulent Jew-hatred being disguised as a noble call for liberation, and we reject it." Congressional leaders from the Democrats and Republicans stood side-by-side on stage to reaffirm bipartisan support for the cause. "We are here united," Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer told the crowd, "Democrat and Republican, House and Senate, to say 'we stand with Israel'." Some speakers also voiced support for the Palestinian people and a desire to see an end to the horrors being endured by civilians in Gaza. Messing said she prayed for a "free and flourishing Gaza", to cheers from the crowd. Today's rally follows a huge pro-Palestinian demonstration in Washington a little over a week ago.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'March for Israel' attracts celebrity & political heavyweights in Washington DC

props.alt: A large crowd with signs and flags can be seen in front of the Capitol building.

children.content: The rally's taken place on the National Mall.
(AP: Jacquelyn Martin)

Speakers have spoken against a rising wave of hate crimes targeting Jews in the US, which the FBI recently warned was reaching "historic levels".

Some speakers also voiced support for the Palestinian people and a desire to see an end to the horrors being endured by civilians in Gaza. Messing said she prayed for a "free and flourishing Gaza", to cheers from the crowd.
Today's rally follows a huge pro-Palestinian demonstration in Washington a little over a week ago.

image.altText: Jarnail Singh holding pieces of paper.

title.children: Man died trying to make it home himself after giving up waiting for a wheelchair taxi

title.children: ASX to jump ahead of third-quarter wage price index, Wall Street rallies as US inflation eased

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NAB is pencilling in a quarter on quarter rise of 1.5%, which is above the Reserve Bank’s implied pick of about 1.3-1.4%. Senior economist Taylor Nugent at NAB said in a note that one-off increase to award salaries in some sector mean the quarterly growth rate will be high and shouldn’t be extrapolated. "The high award wage increase does in part reflect labour market conditions but provides a higher increase than what non-award wages are seeing and will be lower next year," he said. "A 15% level adjustment for more than 250,000 aged care workers does not reflect conditions in the macro backdrop. "We think Wage Price Index will be back around 0.9% quarter on quarter in Q4." The market consensus for the September quarter wage growth is at 1.3%, according to a Reuters poll.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What to expect from the third-quarter wage price index

children.content: NAB is pencilling in a quarter on quarter rise of 1.5%, which is above the Reserve Bank’s implied pick of about 1.3-1.4%.
Senior economist
Taylor Nugent at NAB said in a note that one-off increase to award salaries in some sector mean the quarterly growth rate will be high and shouldn’t be extrapolated.
"The high award wage increase does in part reflect labour market conditions but provides a higher increase than what non-award wages are seeing and will be lower next year," he said.
"A 15% level adjustment for more than 250,000 aged care workers does not reflect conditions in the macro backdrop.
"We think Wage Price Index will be back around 0.9% quarter on quarter in Q4."
The market consensus for the September quarter wage growth is at 1.3%, according to a Reuters poll.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Optus is no stranger to class actions after last year's cyber attack. But a week after its crippling nationwide outage left 10 million Australians in the dark and businesses unable to trade, is another one on the horizon? Legal experts say it's not that straightforward. Read more from business reporter Kate Ainsworth .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Could Optus face a class action over its outage?

featuredLink.title: Optus went offline a week ago, but it could be months before they stare down another class action

Australians in the dark and businesses unable to trade, is another one on the horizon?

Kate Ainsworth

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US stock indexes rallied on Tuesday as cooler-than-expected inflation data boosted expectations that the Federal Reserve was done raising interest rates and could start cutting them next year. The benchmark S & P 500 briefly crossed the 4,500 mark for the first time in two months and the tech-heavy Nasdaq was trading at a fresh two-month high after data showed that growth in US consumer prices eased in October, in part due to lower gasoline prices. In the 12 months through October, the CPI climbed 3.2% after rising 3.7% in September, while economists polled by Reuters had forecast a 3.3% gain on a year-on-year basis. Core prices, which exclude the volatile food and energy components, rose 4.0% compared with economists' estimate of a 4.1% increase. "We're happy to see both headline and core CPI come in lower than expected. It's telling us that the Fed is done, there's nothing left for it to do here," said Thomas Hayes, chairman at hedge fund Great Hill Capital at New York. "This is what the Fed was looking for, slowing inflation, slowing labor market, and the economy's holding up at the same time." Following the data, traders erased bets the Fed would raise borrowing costs any further and piled into bets on rate cuts starting by May. They are currently pricing in a 100% chance the Fed will hold rates next month, as per CME Group's Fedwatch tool. US Treasury yields dropped, with the two-year yield, which best reflects short-term interest rate expectations, sliding to two-week lows. That, in turn, lifted megacap growth stocks such as Nvidia, Alphabet, Amazon and Tesla up between 1.6% and 4.7%. The small-cap Russell 2000 index jumped 4.7% to hit an over six-week high. Rate-sensitive sectors such as real estate and utilities, which have been hammered this year, rose 5.5% and 3.4%, respectively. Wall Street's main indexes have seen a strong rebound in November on expectations that US interest rates were near their peak, even as Fed Chair Jerome Powell last week left the door open to further tightening. Focus is also on negotiations by US lawmakers over a funding bill as they face an end-of-week deadline to fund the federal government.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US inflation inflation cools to 3.2 per cent in October

children.content: US stock indexes rallied on Tuesday as cooler-than-expected inflation data boosted expectations that the Federal Reserve was done raising interest rates and could start cutting them next year.
The benchmark S

P 500 briefly crossed the 4,500 mark for the first time in two months and the tech-heavy Nasdaq was trading at a fresh two-month high after data showed that growth in US consumer prices eased in October, in part due to lower gasoline prices.
In the 12 months through October, the CPI climbed 3.2% after rising 3.7% in September, while economists polled by Reuters had forecast a 3.3% gain on a year-on-year basis.
Core prices, which exclude the volatile food and energy components, rose 4.0% compared with economists' estimate of a 4.1% increase.

"We're happy to see both headline and core CPI come in lower than expected. It's telling us that the Fed is done, there's nothing left for it to do here," said Thomas Hayes, chairman at hedge fund Great Hill Capital at New York.
"This is what the Fed was looking for, slowing inflation, slowing labor market, and the economy's holding up at the same time."
Following the data, traders
erased

bets the Fed would raise borrowing costs any further and piled into bets on rate cuts starting by May. They are currently pricing in a 100% chance the Fed will hold rates next month, as per CME Group's Fedwatch tool.
US Treasury yields dropped, with the two-year yield, which best reflects short-term interest rate expectations, sliding to two-week lows.
That, in turn, lifted megacap growth stocks such as Nvidia, Alphabet, Amazon and Tesla up between 1.6% and 4.7%.

The small-cap Russell 2000 index jumped 4.7% to hit an over six-week high. Rate-sensitive sectors such as real estate and utilities, which have been hammered this year, rose 5.5% and 3.4%, respectively.

Wall Street's main indexes have seen a strong rebound in November on expectations that US interest rates were near their peak, even as Fed Chair Jerome Powell last week left the door open to further tightening.
Focus is also on negotiations by US lawmakers over a funding bill as they face an end-of-week deadline to fund the federal government.
